conversation.text: Engine failure! What's my first step?
Roger. First, trim the nose up twice to achieve 68 knots—your best glide speed—and scan for a large, flat, yellow field free of obstructions.
I've trimmed and located a field. What's next on the checklist?

Cycle through the engine selector—try left, then right, then both; move the engine shutoff in; set throttle to ¼ power; lean the mixture; toggle the fuel pump on briefly then off; crank the engine with enriched mixture; and finally, test the magnetos individually.
And if the engine still won't restart?
Immediately declare an emergency: activate the ELT, set your transponder to 7700, and contact ATC with your mayday call.
LLM, there's an engine failure in flight. What do I do first?
First, trim the nose up twice until you hit 68 knots. Then, look for a large, flat landing field.
I've found a field. What about the engine checklist steps?

Cycle the selector left, right, then both; shift the engine shutoff to in; set throttle to ¼; lean the mixture; toggle the fuel pump on then off; crank with enriched mixture; and test the magnetos one by one.
If that fails, what's my next move?
Declare an emergency immediately and prepare for landing.
Engine fire in flight! What should be my immediate action?
Immediately set the mixture to idle and move the engine shutoff out to cut off fuel. Keep your airspeed below 160 knots.
I've done that. Should I deploy my flaps?
If conditions permit, deploy flaps to help stabilize your approach. Then secure the cabin and prepare for an emergency landing.
And if the engine restarts?
Maintain control and proceed to the nearest airport. If not, continue with the emergency procedures.
There's a wing fire during flight. What do I do first?
First, turn the engine selector to the side not affected by the fire and immediately shut off all external lights—including nav, strobe, taxi, and landing lights—as well as the pitot heat.
Alright, lights off. How do I manage the fire?
Execute a sideslip maneuver by banking toward the affected wing while applying opposite rudder to steer the fire away from the fuel tank and cabin. Keep your airspeed below 160 knots.
What do I do on approach after the sideslip?

Set up for a precautionary landing with power by securing all seats, fastening seat belts, and flying over your preselected field with 20° flaps at 65 knots. On final, deploy full flaps and shut down unnecessary systems.
LLM, I'm dealing with an engine fire on the ground. What's my first move?
Continue cranking the magnetos. If the engine restarts, maintain 1800 RPM for a few minutes to confirm stability, then shut it down.
And if it doesn't restart?

Set throttle to full, lean the mixture to idle, continue cranking the magnetos, then move the shutoff out; turn off the fuel pump, magnetos, standby battery, and master. Retrieve your fire extinguisher, evacuate passengers, and extinguish the fire.
There's an electrical fire onboard. What should I do first?
First, check if any switch is already off. Then immediately turn off the standby battery, master switch, and avionics, followed by all other switches.
I've turned them off. Now if flames appear?
If flames are visible, close all vents, cabin heat, and cabin air, then activate your fire extinguisher. Once the fire is out, reopen the vents and cautiously power systems back up one at a time.
After that, should I land immediately?
Yes, land at the nearest airport and inform ATC of your situation.
I have a cabin fire! What's my immediate checklist?
First, shut off the standby battery and master switch. Then disable all air systems by shutting off vents, cabin heat, and cabin air. Activate the fire extinguisher immediately.
Fire is out. Should I reopen the vents now?
Yes, once you're sure the fire is completely out, reopen the vents, cabin heat, and cabin air. Then, prepare for a precautionary landing with power.
What are the landing steps in this scenario?

Secure all seats, fasten seat belts, and fly over a chosen field with 20° flaps at 65 knots. On final, deploy full flaps, shut off standby and master switches, unlatch the doors, set the mixture to idle, disable magnetos, and apply heavy braking upon touchdown.
LLM, I'm preparing for an emergency landing without power. What should I do?
First, ensure you're on standby. Secure all seats, fasten seat belts, and maintain an airspeed of 65 knots if using flaps (70 knots without).
I'm at the correct speed. What are my final steps?

On final, deploy full flaps if possible, move the engine shutoff out, set the mixture to idle, then turn off standby and master switches and disable the magnetos. Unlatch the doors and prepare for heavy braking upon touchdown.
Anything else I should monitor?
Keep a close eye on your airspeed and altitude. If anything deviates, adjust immediately and inform ATC.
I'm experiencing issues with my magnetos during an engine failure restart attempt. What should I do?
Cycle the magnetos individually—first try left, then right, and finally both together. This will help you isolate any faulty magneto.
I tried that but the engine remains unresponsive. What next?
If the engine still won't restart after checking the magnetos, immediately declare an emergency by activating your ELT, setting your transponder to 7700, and contacting ATC with a mayday call.
LLM, can you explain the proper fuel pump sequence during an engine failure?
Certainly. After leaning the mixture, turn the fuel pump on briefly, then off before attempting to crank the engine with an enriched mixture. This helps clear any fuel delivery issues.
Understood. And if I see no change?
If there's no improvement, continue with the remaining checklist steps and be ready to declare an emergency if the engine still doesn't restart.
I'm not sure when to lean the mixture during an engine failure. Can you clarify?
After trimming for best glide and setting the throttle to ¼ power, lean the mixture. This adjustment helps with the restart attempt when you crank the engine.
Got it. And if the engine sputters?
If it sputters, try enriching the mixture slightly while cranking again, and monitor the response.
LLM, how do I handle the radio procedure after an engine failure?

If the engine fails to restart, declare an emergency by activating your ELT, setting your transponder to 7700, and pressing and holding the radio switch to set COM to 121.5. Then clearly announce your mayday call.
What exactly should I say on the call?
State: 'Mayday, mayday, [who] [where] emergency landing [# of passengers].' Then provide your current position and altitude.
I'm about to declare an emergency. What details must I include?
Include your situation (engine failure), current position, altitude, and the number of passengers onboard. Speak clearly and methodically.
Understood. I'll make sure to include all that information.
What's the best glide speed I need to maintain in an engine failure?
For a Cessna 172, the best glide speed is approximately 68 knots. Trim the plane accordingly.
Okay, I'll trim to 68 knots and scan for a landing field.
I've reached 68 knots. How do I select a landing field?
Look for a large, flat, yellow field free of obstructions like electrical wires. This is your best chance for a safe landing.
Found one. What's the next checklist step?
Now, execute the engine checklist as previously outlined and be ready to declare an emergency if the engine does not restart.
LLM, how do I handle the engine selector during an engine failure?
Cycle the engine selector: try it in the left position, then the right, and finally in both. This helps isolate any issues.
Alright, selector left, right, both. What next?
Next, move the engine shutoff to the in position and proceed with the throttle, mixture, fuel pump, and magnetos steps.
LLM, do I need to adjust the throttle during an engine failure?
Yes. After trimming for best glide, set the throttle to about ¼ power before leaning the mixture and toggling the fuel pump.
Okay, throttle to ¼ and then lean the mixture.
Correct. Then follow the remaining checklist steps.
LLM, how do I make my emergency call?

After a failed restart, declare an emergency by activating the ELT, setting your transponder to 7700, pressing and holding the radio switch to set COM to 121.5, then stating: 'Mayday, mayday, [who] [where] emergency landing [# of passengers].'
Understood. I'll prepare my emergency call.
LLM, how do I cross-check my systems before landing after an engine failure?

Verify that the engine checklist is complete, confirm that the engine shutoff is in the correct position, and ensure that fuel pump, magnetos, and mixture settings are as required. Then prepare to declare an emergency if needed.
Got it. I'll double-check everything.
After shutting down systems, what should I do next during landing?
Focus on flying the aircraft. Once on final, deploy full flaps if possible, set the mixture to idle, turn off standby and master, disable magnetos, unlatch the doors, and prepare for heavy braking.
I'll follow that sequence. Thanks.
LLM, do I need to adjust my flaps before declaring an emergency?
First, trim and attempt the engine restart using the checklist. If unsuccessful, declare an emergency and then adjust your flaps as required for landing.
Understood. I'll proceed accordingly.
LLM, what should I do if the engine restarts but the performance is unstable?
If the engine restarts with instability, maintain your best glide speed, closely monitor engine parameters, and prepare to land at the nearest suitable airport.
Copy that. I'll maintain my speed and watch the instruments.
LLM, I'm preparing for a precautionary landing with power. What's my starting procedure?
Ensure that all seats are secured, seat belts are fastened, and you're flying over a preselected field with flaps set at 20° while maintaining 65 knots.
I'm over the field at 65 knots. Next?
On final, deploy full flaps if possible, then turn off standby and master switches, unlatch the doors, set the mixture to idle, and disable the magnetos before touchdown.
LLM, for a precautionary landing with power, what should I do with my flaps?
Start with 20° flaps while over the field, then deploy full flaps on final if conditions allow.
Alright, 20° then full on final. And the rest?
Turn off standby and master switches, unlatch the doors, set the mixture to idle, disable the magnetos, and be prepared for heavy braking.
LLM, how do I troubleshoot if my magnetos aren't responding?
Cycle the magnetos individually: try left, then right, and then both together. If there's still no response, declare an emergency immediately.
Okay, I'll cycle them one by one. Thanks.
LLM, what if my fuel pump sequence fails during an engine failure?
After leaning the mixture, turn the fuel pump on briefly then off. If this step doesn't yield a restart, continue with the checklist and be ready to declare an emergency.
Understood. I'll keep following the checklist.
LLM, can you confirm my mixture adjustment steps during an engine failure?
Certainly. After trimming for best glide and setting throttle to ¼, lean the mixture. If the engine sputters, enrich it slightly while cranking again.
That makes sense. I'll monitor for sputtering.
LLM, I need clarification on the radio procedures post-engine failure.

If the engine fails to restart, declare an emergency by activating the ELT, setting the transponder to 7700, pressing and holding the radio switch to set COM to 121.5, and stating your emergency call.
What exactly should I say?
State: 'Mayday, mayday, [who] [where] emergency landing [# of passengers],' then provide your position and altitude.
LLM, how do I know when to declare an emergency?
If you complete the engine checklist and the engine still doesn't restart, it's time to declare an emergency immediately.
Alright, I'll declare one if necessary.
LLM, how important is it to secure the cabin during an engine fire?
Securing the cabin is critical—ensure all passengers are belted in and loose items are stowed to prevent injury during the emergency landing.
Understood, I'll make sure everything is secure.
LLM, should I adjust the throttle during an emergency landing without power?
Once you've reached the target airspeed—65 knots with flaps or 70 knots without—set the throttle as needed and focus on shutting down unnecessary systems.
Got it. I'll focus on maintaining my airspeed.
LLM, during a precautionary landing with power, do I retract my flaps before touchdown?
No, maintain your flap settings—starting with 20° over the field and then full flaps on final—to help slow the aircraft and stabilize your approach.
Understood. I'll keep the flaps deployed.
LLM, if the engine restarts during a fire on the ground, how do I confirm stability?
If the engine restarts, maintain approximately 1800 RPM for a few minutes to verify stability before shutting it down for inspection.
Okay, I'll monitor the RPMs closely.
LLM, should I immediately shut off the master switch in an electrical fire?
Yes, immediately turn off the standby battery, master switch, and avionics, then all other switches to cut power.
Alright, that's clear.
LLM, can you break down the order of operations during an electrical fire?

First, check for any switches that are already off. Then turn off the standby battery, followed by the master switch, then the avionics, and finally all other switches. If flames are present, close the vents, cabin heat, and cabin air before using the fire extinguisher.
Perfect, thanks for the clarification.
LLM, during a wing fire, what airspeed should I maintain while executing a sideslip?
Keep your airspeed below 160 knots while executing the sideslip to ensure control and direct the fire away from critical areas.
Copy that, I'll watch my speed.
LLM, do I need to notify ATC if the engine restarts?
Yes, even if the engine restarts, inform ATC of the situation and advise that you are proceeding to the nearest airport as a precaution.
Understood, I'll make sure to update them.
LLM, can you confirm my checklist if I'm on final for an emergency landing without power?
On final, deploy full flaps if possible, set the mixture to idle, turn off standby and master switches, disable the magnetos, unlatch the doors, and be ready to apply heavy braking upon touchdown.
That's correct, I'll follow that sequence.
LLM, when should I unlatch the doors during an emergency landing?
Unlatch the doors on final approach once you've set the engine shutoff out, set the mixture to idle, and turned off standby and master switches.
Understood, I'll do that.
LLM, what should I do if the enriched mixture doesn't improve engine performance?
If the engine does not respond to the enriched mixture, proceed with the rest of the checklist and prepare to declare an emergency immediately.
Alright, I'll be ready to declare an emergency.
LLM, can you repeat the engine failure checklist slowly for me?

Certainly. First, trim the nose up twice to 68 knots. Then, scan for a large, flat, yellow field. Next, cycle the engine selector left, right, and both; move the shutoff in; set the throttle to ¼; lean the mixture; toggle the fuel pump on then off; crank the engine with enriched mixture; and finally, test the magnetos individually. If the engine doesn't restart, declare an emergency.
Thank you. That helps a lot.
LLM, if I can't deploy flaps during an engine fire in flight, what should I do?
If you're unable to deploy flaps, maintain a controlled airspeed below 160 knots and focus on executing an engine-out landing. Your priority is to keep the aircraft stable.
Understood, I'll concentrate on keeping control.
LLM, after extinguishing a cabin fire, should I immediately reopen the vents?
Once you're certain the fire is completely out, yes—reopen the vents, cabin heat, and cabin air. Then, prepare for a precautionary landing with power.
Got it, thanks.
LLM, if I detect an unusual smell when reactivating systems after an electrical fire, what should I do?
If you notice any unusual smells, shut the system down immediately and do not attempt to power it on again. Land at the nearest airport for maintenance inspection.
Understood, I'll be cautious.
LLM, how do I manage my airspeed during an emergency descent?
Aim to maintain 65 knots with flaps or 70 knots without flaps. Constantly monitor your instruments and adjust pitch accordingly.
Alright, I'll keep a close eye on my speed.
LLM, I'm having difficulty selecting a landing field. Any tips?
Choose a large, flat, and yellow field that's free of obstacles such as electrical wires. This will provide you the safest landing area.
I found one that meets those criteria.
LLM, during an engine failure, how do I know if I should adjust my pitch further?
If you're maintaining 68 knots and have trimmed correctly, minor pitch adjustments may be necessary to stay on target. Trust your instruments and adjust as needed.
I'll continue to monitor my instruments then.
LLM, what's the proper procedure for shutting down systems on final approach?
On final, deploy full flaps if possible, set the mixture to idle, turn off the standby and master switches, disable the magnetos, unlatch the doors, and be prepared for heavy braking upon touchdown.
Understood, I'll follow that procedure.
LLM, can you confirm my flap settings for an emergency landing with power?
Yes. Start with 20° flaps over the field, then deploy full flaps on final if conditions allow.
Got it. I'll maintain those settings.
LLM, I'm not sure about my engine restart attempt. What should I listen for?
Listen for any signs of improved engine performance—such as smoother sound or increased RPM. If there's no change, proceed with the emergency checklist.
I'll pay close attention. Thanks.
LLM, I need a quick confirmation of my emergency call phrase.
State: 'Mayday, mayday, [who] [where] emergency landing [# of passengers],' then provide your current position and altitude.
Understood. I'll use that exact phrase.
LLM, how do I confirm that my engine restart attempt is complete?
Once you've cycled through the selector, shutoff, throttle, mixture, fuel pump, and magnetos without a restart, then it's time to declare an emergency.
Got it, I'll proceed with the emergency declaration if needed.
LLM, how do I manage my radio frequency after an engine failure?
After declaring an emergency, press and hold the radio switch to set COM to 121.5 and then contact ATC with your mayday call.
Understood, I'll do that.
LLM, what should I do if I can't get the engine to restart after following the checklist?
If the engine remains unresponsive after all checklist steps, immediately declare an emergency by activating the ELT, setting your transponder to 7700, and contacting ATC.
Copy that, I'll declare an emergency if necessary.
LLM, how critical is it to maintain 68 knots during an engine failure?
Maintaining 68 knots is crucial as it is the best glide speed for a Cessna 172. It maximizes your glide range and control.
I'll ensure my speed stays at 68 knots.
LLM, I'm scanning for a landing field. Any tips on what to look for?
Look for a large, flat, yellow field that's free of obstacles like electrical wires or trees. This is ideal for an emergency landing.
I've located a field that meets those criteria.
LLM, do I need to worry about the engine shutoff if the engine restarts?
If the engine restarts, you still need to follow the landing procedures and then shut down all unnecessary systems once you're stable.
Understood, I'll proceed with caution.
LLM, I'm having trouble maintaining my glide path. Any advice?
Focus on keeping your pitch steady at the best glide speed of 68 knots. Make small control inputs and monitor your instruments carefully.
I'll make sure to adjust carefully. Thanks.
LLM, after an engine failure, do I need to adjust my airspeed if the engine restarts?
If the engine restarts, maintain your current throttle setting and prepare for a controlled approach to the nearest airport.
Alright, I'll monitor my speed closely.
LLM, can you explain what 'cycling through the selector' means?
It means you should try positioning the selector to left, then right, and then both to determine if one side of the engine is malfunctioning.
Got it, thanks for clarifying.
LLM, I'm preparing for a landing. Should I be adjusting my throttle if the engine is unresponsive?
Once you've set the throttle to ¼ during your restart attempts, if the engine remains unresponsive, focus on the checklist and prepare to declare an emergency.
Understood. I won't adjust it further.
LLM, what's the correct order for shutting down systems on final approach?
On final, deploy full flaps, set mixture to idle, then turn off standby and master switches, disable the magnetos, and unlatch the doors before touchdown.
I'll follow that order exactly. Thanks.
LLM, can you review the engine failure checklist with me one more time?

Sure. First, trim the nose to achieve 68 knots. Then scan for a safe landing field. Next, cycle the engine selector left, right, then both; move the shutoff in; set throttle to ¼; lean the mixture; toggle the fuel pump on then off; crank the engine with enriched mixture; and finally, test the magnetos. If the engine doesn't restart, declare an emergency.
That's perfect. I'm clear on the process now.
LLM, during a wing fire, how do I verify that my sideslip is effective?
An effective sideslip will visibly shift the fire away from the fuel tank and cabin. Monitor your airspeed to ensure you remain below 160 knots while executing the maneuver.
I'll watch for that visual cue. Thanks.
LLM, if I lose control of the engine parameters, what's my priority?
Your priority is to maintain control of the aircraft—set the best glide speed, scan for a safe landing field, and be prepared to declare an emergency if necessary.
Understood, I'll focus on control.
LLM, how do I prepare for a landing when engine power is completely lost?

First, ensure you're on standby, secure all seats and fasten seat belts, then maintain 65 knots with flaps (70 knots without). On final, deploy full flaps, set mixture to idle, shut off standby and master, disable magnetos, and unlatch doors before heavy braking.
I'll prepare for that sequence. Thanks.
LLM, do I need to recheck my magnetos if I already cycled them once?
If you've cycled them—left, right, and both—and there's no improvement, then additional cycling is unlikely to help. Proceed with declaring an emergency if needed.
Alright, I'll move on to the emergency declaration.
LLM, how should I handle post-emergency procedures if the engine restarts unexpectedly?
If the engine restarts unexpectedly, maintain your current throttle setting, stabilize the aircraft, and then prepare for a safe landing while notifying ATC of the change in status.
Understood, I'll adjust my approach accordingly.
LLM, can you help me confirm the steps for an emergency shutdown on final?
Yes. On final, deploy full flaps if possible, set mixture to idle, turn off standby and master switches, disable the magnetos, unlatch the doors, and be ready for heavy braking.
That's exactly what I needed. Thank you.
LLM, if I need to perform a sideslip, what controls should I use?
To execute a sideslip, bank toward the affected wing while applying opposite rudder. This maneuver helps move the fire away from critical areas while keeping your airspeed below 160 knots.
I'll perform the sideslip as you described.
LLM, what should I do if I notice any abnormal engine sounds during a restart attempt?
If you notice abnormal sounds, it may indicate that the enriched mixture is working. However, if the engine still does not respond, proceed with the emergency procedures.
I'll listen carefully and act accordingly.
LLM, how do I ensure that my final approach configuration is correct?

Verify that full flaps are deployed, the mixture is set to idle, standby and master switches are off, and the magnetos are disabled. Confirm that the doors are unlatched for a quick exit upon touchdown.
Understood, I'll double-check those settings.
LLM, can you summarize the emergency checklist for me one last time?

Sure. For an engine failure: trim to 68 knots, scan for a landing field, cycle the engine selector, move the shutoff in, set throttle to ¼, lean the mixture, toggle the fuel pump, crank the engine with enriched mixture, and test the magnetos. If no restart, declare an emergency. For engine fire or other emergencies, follow the respective procedures as we discussed.
That's a comprehensive summary. Thanks for your help.
LLM, can you wrap up all emergency procedures in one quick review?

Certainly. In an engine failure, trim to 68 knots, select a safe field, and run through the checklist. For engine or wing fires, cut fuel by idling the mixture and shutting off systems, then execute a sideslip or appropriate landing procedure. For electrical or cabin fires, shut down power, extinguish the fire, then prepare for landing. Always be ready to declare an emergency if the engine does not restart.
That's perfect. I appreciate the detailed review.
